Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Stink \Stink\, v. t. To cause to stink; to affect by a stink. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Stink \Stink\, n. [AS. stinc.] A strong, offensive smell; a disgusting odor; a stench. [1913 Webster]
{Fire stink}. See under {Fire}.
{Stink-fire lance}. See under {Lance}.
{Stink rat} (Zo["o]l.), the musk turtle. [Local, U.S.]
{Stink shad} (Zo["o]l.), the gizzard shad. [Local, U.S.]
{Stink trap}, a stench trap. See under {Stench}. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Stink \Stink\, v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Stunk}, {Stank}, p. pr. & vb. n. {Stinking}.] [AS. stinkan to have a smell (whether good or bad); akin to OHG. stinchan, G. & D. stinken to stink; of uncertain origin; cf. Icel. st["o]kkva to leap, to spring, Goth. stigqan to push, strike, or Gr. ? rancid. Cf. {Stench}.] To emit a strong, offensive smell; to send out a disgusting odor. [1913 Webster]

stink n : a distinctive odor that is offensively unpleasant [syn: {malodor}, {malodour}, {stench}, {reek}, {fetor}, {foetor}, {mephitis}] v 1: be extremely bad in quality or in one's performance; "This term paper stinks!" 2: smell badly and offensively; "The building reeks of smoke" [syn: {reek}] [also: {stunk}, {stank}]
